project.spec:
# Arij

A local, AI-first project orchestrator that provides a web interface for managing multi-project workflows with Claude Code as the execution engine. It covers the full project lifecycle: ideation, specification, kanban-based planning, automated code generation via Claude Code CLI, real-time agent monitoring, and release management.

## Stack
Next.js 16 (App Router, Turbopack), React 19, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS v4, shadcn/ui, SQLite via better-sqlite3, Drizzle ORM, dnd-kit (kanban drag-and-drop), Claude Code CLI (child_process spawn), simple-git (worktrees/branches), mammoth (DOCX→MD), pdf-parse (PDF→MD), unified/remark/rehype (Markdown processing), nanoid (ID generation)

## Architecture
Full-stack Next.js 16 application with App Router. Frontend uses React 19 with shadcn/ui components and dnd-kit for the kanban board. Backend is Next.js API routes that interact with a local SQLite database via Drizzle ORM. Claude Code integration spawns the `claude` CLI as child processes (plan mode for brainstorming/spec generation, code mode for epic implementation). Git worktrees provide isolated branches per epic. File converters transform uploaded documents (PDF, DOCX) to Markdown for context injection. Real-time monitoring uses polling. All data is local-first with no cloud dependencies.

epics.title: Agent Configuration Side Panel & Custom Review Agents
epics.description:
Dedicated side panel for configuring agent prompts (global + per-project override), creating custom review agents, and setting the default AI provider per agent type.

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1 — Schema & Data Layer

**Agent Prompts Table:**
- Add `agentPrompts` table: id, agentType (text: 'build', 'review_security', 'review_code', 'review_compliance', 'chat', 'spec_generation', 'team_build', 'ticket_build'), systemPrompt (text), scope ('global' | projectId), createdAt, updatedAt
- Global prompts have scope='global', project overrides store the projectId
- When resolving a prompt, project-scoped prompt takes precedence over global, which takes precedence over built-in defaults

**Custom Review Agents Table:**
- Add `customReviewAgents` table: id, name (text), systemPrompt (text), scope ('global' | projectId), position (integer), isEnabled (integer, default 1), createdAt, updatedAt
- Custom review agents are user-defined and appear alongside the 3 built-in review types

**Agent Provider Defaults Table:**
- Add `agentProviderDefaults` table: id, agentType (text), provider ('claude-code' | 'codex'), scope ('global' | projectId), createdAt, updatedAt
- Allows setting CC or Codex as default per agent type, with project override

### Phase 2 — API Routes

**Agent Prompts:**
- `GET /api/agent-config/prompts` — list all global agent prompts
- `GET /api/projects/[projectId]/agent-config/prompts` — list project-scoped prompts (merged with global defaults)
- `PUT /api/agent-config/prompts/[agentType]` — upsert global prompt for an agent type
- `PUT /api/projects/[projectId]/agent-config/prompts/[agentType]` — upsert project override
- `DELETE /api/projects/[projectId]/agent-config/prompts/[agentType]` — remove project override (fall back to global)

**Custom Review Agents:**
- `GET /api/agent-config/review-agents` — list global custom review agents
- `GET /api/projects/[projectId]/agent-config/review-agents` — list project-scoped + global review agents
- `POST /api/agent-config/review-agents` — create a custom review agent (global)
- `POST /api/projects/[projectId]/agent-config/review-agents` — create project-scoped review agent
- `PATCH /api/agent-config/review-agents/[agentId]` — update name, prompt, enabled status
- `DELETE /api/agent-config/review-agents/[agentId]` — delete a custom review agent

**Agent Provider Defaults:**
- `GET /api/agent-config/providers` — list global provider defaults per agent type
- `PUT /api/agent-config/providers/[agentType]` — set global default provider for agent type
- `PUT /api/projects/[projectId]/agent-config/providers/[agentType]` — set project override

### Phase 3 — Prompt Builder Integration
- Refactor all prompt builder functions to load custom prompts from DB before composing
- Resolution order: project override → global custom → built-in default
- Update `buildReviewPrompt` to accept custom review agent prompts in addition to built-in types
- Update `buildBuildPrompt`, `buildChatPrompt`, `buildSpecPrompt`, `buildTeamBuildPrompt`, `buildTicketBuildPrompt` to use configurable prompts

### Phase 4 — Side Panel UI
- New `AgentConfigPanel` component accessible from the main sidebar
- Three tabs: **Agent Prompts**, **Review Agents**, **Provider Defaults**
- Agent Prompts tab: list of agent types with expandable prompt editors, toggle between global/project scope
- Review Agents tab: list of built-in (read-only name) + custom review agents, each with name/prompt fields, add/delete actions
- Provider Defaults tab: per-agent-type dropdown to select CC or Codex as default
- Panel slides in from the left sidebar, can be toggled open/closed

### Phase 5 — Review Dialog Integration
- Update the Agent Review dialog on the story detail page to include custom review agents alongside the 3 built-in types
- Custom agents displayed as additional checkboxes with their name
- Each selected custom agent dispatches a plan-mode agent with the custom prompt
- Agent output posted as a comment with the custom agent's name as label

epics.title: Agent Teams & Codex Provider Integration
epics.description:
Two-part feature: (1) Agent Teams mode that leverages Claude Code's native Task tool to delegate multiple tickets to sub-agents in a single session, and (2) OpenAI Codex integration as an alternative AI provider alongside Claude Code.

## Implementation Plan

### Part A — Agent Teams (Claude Code Only)

**Schema & Data Layer:**
- Add `orchestrationMode` column to `agentSessions` table (`'solo' | 'team'`, default `'solo'`)
- Team mode is exclusive to Claude Code (Codex has no equivalent sub-agent delegation)

**Prompt Builder:**
- New `buildTeamBuildPrompt()` function that describes all selected epics with their worktree paths
- Instructs Claude Code to act as a team lead and use the `Task` tool to spawn sub-agents per ticket
- Lets CC decide team composition and size

**Build Route Changes:**
- When `team=true` in the batch build request, pre-create all git worktrees for selected epics
- Spawn a single CC session from the main repo root (not inside a worktree)
- Add `Task` to the `--allowedTools` list for team mode
- Track as a single `agentSession` with `orchestrationMode: 'team'`
- On completion, update all associated epics' statuses

**UI — Build Toolbar:**
- Add 'Team mode' checkbox in the build toolbar, visible when 2+ epics are selected
- Checkbox disabled when fewer than 2 epics selected or when provider is Codex
- Tooltip explains team mode behavior

### Part B — Codex Provider Integration

**Provider Abstraction Layer:**
- New `lib/providers/` directory with provider interface (`AgentProvider`)
- `lib/providers/claude-code.ts` — wraps existing CC spawn logic
- `lib/providers/codex.ts` — wraps `@openai/codex-sdk` using `Codex` class, `startThread()`, `runStreamed()` for streaming events
- `lib/providers/index.ts` — factory function `getProvider(type: 'claude-code' | 'codex')`
- Codex provider uses `workingDirectory` option on `startThread()` for worktree paths

**Schema Changes:**
- Add `provider` column to `agentSessions` (`'claude-code' | 'codex'`, default `'claude-code'`)
- Add `provider` column to `chatConversations` (if table exists) or chat messages

**Process Manager Generalization:**
- Refactor `lib/claude/process-manager.ts` to accept provider-agnostic session handles
- Codex sessions tracked via thread ID, CC sessions tracked via PID
- Unified start/cancel/status interface

**Build & Review Routes:**
- Build route accepts `provider` parameter, dispatches via provider factory
- Review route accepts `provider` parameter
- Send-to-dev route accepts `provider` parameter

**UI — Provider Selector:**
- Dropdown in build toolbar to choose between Claude Code and Codex
- Provider selector in Send to Dev dialog
- Provider selector in Agent Review dialog
- Provider toggle in chat header (locked/disabled after first message in conversation)
- Codex option disabled with tooltip if no API key configured

**Settings:**
- Add Codex API key field to Settings page
- Stored in `settings` table with key `codex_api_key`
- Validated on save (non-empty string check)

**Codex SDK Integration Details:**
- Install `@openai/codex-sdk` dependency
- Use `new Codex({ env: { CODEX_API_KEY: ... } })` with API key from settings
- `startThread({ workingDirectory })` for worktree-scoped execution
- `runStreamed()` for streaming events, map to unified event format
- Thread IDs stored in session metadata for resumption support

epics.title: Ticket Comments, Send-to-Dev & Agent Review
epics.description:
Add a comment system to user stories (tickets), a dedicated story detail page replacing the sheet, and review workflows powered by Claude Code agents.

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1 — Schema & Data Layer
- Add `ticketComments` table (id, userStoryId, author: 'user'|'agent', content, agentSessionId?, createdAt)
- Add `userStoryId` column to `agentSessions` to link agent work back to a specific ticket
- Add `"review"` as a valid status for user stories (todo → in_progress → review → done)

### Phase 2 — API Routes
- `GET/PATCH /api/projects/[projectId]/stories/[storyId]` — fetch & update story detail
- `GET/POST /api/projects/[projectId]/stories/[storyId]/comments` — list & add comments
- `POST /api/projects/[projectId]/stories/[storyId]/build` — dispatch a code-mode agent for the ticket (send-to-dev)
- `POST /api/projects/[projectId]/stories/[storyId]/review` — dispatch review agents (security, code-review, compliance/accessibility)

### Phase 3 — Hooks
- `useStoryDetail` — fetch story with epic context
- `useComments` — fetch comments with 5s polling
- `useTicketAgent` — dispatch agent + poll session status, auto-post final output as agent comment

### Phase 4 — Story Detail Page
- New route: `/projects/[projectId]/stories/[storyId]`
- Two-column layout: left = story details (title, description, acceptance criteria, status, priority), right = comment thread
- Navigate to this page by clicking story titles in the epic detail view

### Phase 5 — Send to Dev
- Available on tickets in `todo` or `in_progress` status
- "Send to Dev" button opens a dialog with an optional comment field
- On confirm: post comment (if provided), dispatch code-mode agent with ticket context + full comment history, move ticket to `in_progress`
- Agent reuses the epic's existing git worktree/branch with concurrency guard

### Phase 6 — Agent Review (Review status)
- Available on tickets in `review` status
- "Send to Dev" button (requires mandatory comment explaining what to fix) → dispatches code agent, moves ticket back to `in_progress`
- "Agent Review" button opens dialog with 3 checkboxes: Security, Code Review, Compliance/Accessibility
- Each selected review type dispatches a separate agent in plan mode with a specialized review checklist
- Agent outputs are posted as comments on the ticket

### Phase 7 — Approve & Merge
- "Approve" action on review-status tickets marks the ticket as `done`
- Triggers merge of the epic's worktree branch into the target branch

### Prompt Builder
- `buildTicketBuildPrompt` — code mode, includes project spec, epic context, ticket details, and full comment history
- `buildReviewPrompt` — plan mode, 3 specialized checklists (security audit, code review best practices, compliance/accessibility standards)

epics.title: Chat Image Upload & Clipboard Paste
epics.description:
Add image support to chat panels — users can upload images via a file picker or paste them from the clipboard. Images are saved locally, displayed as thumbnails before sending, and rendered inline in chat messages.

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1 — Storage & Schema
- Create `data/uploads/` directory for storing chat image files (gitignored)
- Add `chatAttachments` table to Drizzle schema (id, chatMessageId FK, fileName, filePath, mimeType, sizeBytes, createdAt)
- Add cascade delete from chatMessages to chatAttachments
- Generate and push migration

### Phase 2 — Upload API
- Create `POST /api/projects/[projectId]/chat/upload` route
- Accept multipart form data with image files (png, jpg, jpeg, gif, webp)
- Validate file type and size (max 10MB per file)
- Save files to `data/uploads/{projectId}/{nanoid}-{originalName}`
- Return attachment metadata (id, fileName, filePath, mimeType)
- Create `GET /api/projects/[projectId]/chat/uploads/[attachmentId]` to serve images

### Phase 3 — Enhanced MessageInput Component
- Add paste event handler on the textarea to intercept `clipboardData.items` with `type.startsWith('image/')`
- Convert pasted image blobs to File objects and upload immediately
- Add image upload button (paperclip/image icon) next to the send button
- Hidden file input accepting image MIME types, triggered by the button
- Display pending image thumbnails in a preview strip above the textarea
- Allow removing individual thumbnails before sending
- On send, include attachment IDs alongside the message content

### Phase 4 — Message Rendering
- Update MessageList / MarkdownContent to detect and render images associated with messages
- Fetch attachments for each message and display them as inline images below the text
- Support lightbox/modal view on image click for full-size viewing
- Lazy-load images with placeholder skeleton

### Phase 5 — Chat API Integration
- Update `POST /api/projects/[projectId]/chat/messages` to accept an optional `attachmentIds` array
- Link uploaded attachments to the created message
- Update `GET /api/projects/[projectId]/chat/messages` to include attachment metadata in response
- Ensure attachments are cleaned up when messages are deleted (cascade)

epics.title: Unified Chat & Epic Creation Side Panel
epics.description:
Rework the separate chat panel and epic creation flow into a single unified side panel component. The panel lives on the right side of the screen, collapsed by default (showing ~5% as a grayed-out edge). Clicking 'Chat' or 'New Epic' expands the panel, splitting the screen into a resizable two-pane layout (board + chat). The panel supports tabbed conversations with agent activity indicators and mandatory agent type selection on each new chat.

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1 — Unified Panel Shell
- Create a `UnifiedChatPanel` component that replaces the current separate chat panel and epic creation chat
- Panel has three visual states: collapsed (5% visible, grayed overlay on the right edge), expanded (resizable split with the board), and hidden (0%)
- Default state is collapsed — a thin vertical strip visible on the right side
- Clicking the collapsed strip or toolbar buttons ('Chat', 'New Epic') transitions to expanded state
- Use a resizable split layout (e.g. `react-resizable-panels` or custom CSS resize) so the user can drag the divider between the board and the chat panel
- Persist the panel width in local state (or localStorage) so it remembers the user's preferred split

### Phase 2 — Tabbed Conversations
- The panel supports multiple open conversations as tabs (similar to browser tabs)
- Each tab represents a chat conversation (brainstorm, epic creation, or general)
- Tabs show the conversation title (truncated) and a close button
- A '+' button creates a new tab
- Active tab is visually highlighted
- Tab state persisted in the existing `chatMessages` / `chatConversations` DB tables

### Phase 3 — Agent Activity Indicator in Tabs
- When an agent is actively working on a conversation (streaming response, building, etc.), display a small animated icon (spinner or pulsing dot) on the corresponding tab
- The indicator is visible even when the panel is collapsed, appearing on the thin right-edge strip as a subtle glow or badge
- Poll agent session status to determine which conversations have active agents

### Phase 4 — Agent Type Selector on New Chat
- When creating a new conversation ('+' tab or 'New Epic' / 'Chat' trigger), show a mandatory agent type selector before the first message
- Agent types: 'Brainstorm' (plan mode), 'Epic Creation' (spec generation mode), or custom types from agent config
- The selected type determines the prompt builder and Claude Code mode used
- Selector displayed as a prominent dropdown or button group at the top of the empty chat
- Once the first message is sent, the agent type is locked for that conversation

### Phase 5 — Board Integration
- Remove the old chat panel toggle from the project header
- The kanban board occupies 100% width when the panel is collapsed
- When expanded, the board flexes to fill the remaining space
- 'New Epic' button in the board toolbar opens the panel with a new 'Epic Creation' tab pre-selected
- 'Chat' button opens the panel with a new 'Brainstorm' tab or focuses the last active tab
- Ensure the kanban board remains fully functional (drag-and-drop, selection, build toolbar) in the reduced width

user_stories.description: Create the unified panel shell with a collapsed state showing approximately 5% of the screen width as a grayed-out vertical strip on the right side. The strip should have a subtle visual cue (e.g. a chat icon or vertical text) indicating it can be expanded. Clicking anywhere on the strip expands the panel.

- [ ] Collapsed panel renders as a thin vertical strip (~5% width) on the right edge
- [ ] Strip has a muted/grayed appearance distinct from the main content
- [ ] Subtle visual indicator (icon or label) on the strip hints at chat functionality
- [ ] Clicking the strip transitions the panel to the expanded state
- [ ] Panel defaults to collapsed state on page load
- [ ] Smooth CSS transition between collapsed and expanded states

A draggable divider allows resizing. The board and panel each have a minimum width to remain usable. The user's preferred width ratio persists across sessions via localStorage.
